title: 106_hr4730
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia are descendants and political successors to the original Creek Indian Nation at the time of European contact and signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, with over 2,500 eligible members, chose not to be removed under the 1832 Treaty of Washington and continued to operate as a sovereign tribe within Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, with over 2,500 eligible members, declined removal under the 1832 Treaty of Washington and remains a sovereign tribe with a viable tribal government. In 1972, the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia petitioned for Federal recognition but lacked proper legal counsel and historical information, hindering their efforts. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia's petition for Federal recognition in 1972 was denied due to technical omissions, lacking critical historical information. Despite this denial, the Tribe's political leaders have been recognized by the Federal Government, the government of Georgia, and local governments. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Member: Enrolled member of the Tribe as of enactment or placed on membership rolls.
(2) Secretary: Secretary of the Interior.
(3) Tribe: Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia.

SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. The Tribe and its members are eligible for all Federal benefits and services provided to federally recognized Indian tribes without the need for a reservation. Federal benefits and services are provided to federally recognized Indian tribes and their members regardless of the existence of a reservation or the member's residence on or near an Indian reservation. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 applies to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RESERVATION. The Tribe can transfer land to the Secretary for trust within 2 years, establishing the initial reservation land. Gaming is prohibited on the trust land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. The Secretary will publish the roll in the Federal Register, and the Tribe is responsible for keeping it current. The Tribe has the right to determine future membership. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. The roll will be published in the Federal Register and must be kept current. Future membership is determined by the Tribe, with individuals needing to be lineal descendants on the base membership roll and maintain political relations with the Tribe. The reservation established by this Act will be under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. This Act will not affect any treaties or rights secured by treaties for the tribes mentioned in the Act.
